content:
TITLE: Define Entity Properties (YAML) DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates various ways to define entity properties, including the short syntax for strings and the long syntax for specifying the property type and options. It covers properties like name, content, publishedAt, authorEmail and status. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` name: Blog about cats entities: Post üìù: properties: - name # Short syntax for string type. - { name: content, type: text } # Long syntax for other types. - { name: publishedAt, type: date } - { name: authorEmail, type: email, hidden: true } # Extra options. - { name: status, type: choice, options: { values: [draft, pending, published] }, default: draft # Default value if property not specified. } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Entity Relations in Manifest DESCRIPTION: This YAML snippet demonstrates how to define relations between entities in Manifest, including 'belongsTo' (many-to-one) and 'belongsToMany' (many-to-many) relationships. It showcases the relationship between Player, Team, Skill, and Fixture entities within a Basketball League, highlighting the bi-directional nature of relations and the use of the long syntax for relation customization. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_20 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` name: Basketball League üèÄ entities: Player ü§æ: properties: - name belongsTo: - Team belongsToMany: - Skill Team üë•: properties: - name Skill üí™: properties: - name Fixture üèüÔ∏è: properties: - { name: homeScore, type: number } - { name: awayScore, type: number } belongsTo: - { name: homeTeam, entity: Team } - { name: awayTeam, entity: Team } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Define Validation Rules in backend.yml (YAML) DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to define validation rules for properties within the `backend.yml` file using the block syntax. It shows examples for `name` and `age` properties, specifying minimum length and range constraints respectively. This configuration ensures that the data received conforms to the defined rules before processing. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/validation.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` entities: Dog: properties: - name - { name: age, type: number } validation: name: { minLength: 3 } # The name should have at least 3 characters. age: { min: 1, max: 30 } # Age should be a number between 1 and 30. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configuring Webhooks in manifest/backend.yml (YAML) DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to define webhooks for entity events in the `manifest/backend.yml` file. It demonstrates attaching webhooks to `beforeCreate` and `afterDelete` events, including specifying URLs, headers with environment variable interpolation, and HTTP methods. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/webhooks.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` entities: # You can attach one or several webhooks to each entity event. Cat üò∫: properties: - name hooks: beforeCreate: - { url: 'https://my-webhook.com' } Dog üê∂: properties: - name hooks: afterDelete: # Pass .env variables with ${} interpolation. - { url: 'https://another-webhook.com', headers: { authorization: 'Bearer ${API_KEY}' } } # Specific HTTP method. - { url: 'https://another-one.com', method: 'PATCH' } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: REST API Authorization HTTP DESCRIPTION: This HTTP request example shows how to include the JWT token in the `Authorization` header of a request. The token is prefixed with `Bearer` and included in the header. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: HTTP CODE: ``` GET /api/dynamic/cats Content-Type: application/json Authorization: Bearer your-token-here ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Define Entities with Properties (YAML) DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to define two entities, Cat and Dog, each with a name property, in the backend.yml file. It demonstrates the basic structure for defining entities within the Manifest framework. It showcases the short syntax for defining string properties. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` name: A pet app entities: Cat üò∫: properties: - name Dog üê∂: properties: - name ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Upload Image with REST API DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to upload an image using the Manifest REST API. It specifies the POST request to `/api/upload/image` with `multipart/form-data`, including the expected structure of the request body and the response containing thumbnail and medium image paths. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/upload.md#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` // Upload image. POST /api/upload/image Content-Type: multipart/form-data { image: (binary) entity: cats property: avatar } // Response. { "medium": "http://localhost:1111/cats/avatar/Oct2024/8dabo9qm1q4n1nk-medium.jpg", "thumbnail": "http://localhost:1111/cats/avatar/Oct2024/8dabo9qm1q4n1nk-thumbnail.jpg" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Environment Variable Configuration DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the required environment variables for a Manifest deployment. It defines the token secret key, sets the environment to production, and configures the base URL. These variables are crucial for the application to function correctly in a production environment. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/deploy.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: env CODE: ``` TOKEN_SECRET_KEY=%ReplaceByYourKey% NODE_ENV=production BASE_URL=https://my-backend.com ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a simple endpoint in YAML DESCRIPTION: This YAML code defines a simple endpoint named 'helloWorld' that responds to GET requests at the '/hello-world' path. It specifies the handler function to be 'helloWorld'. This configures the Manifest backend to route requests to the defined handler. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/endpoints.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` endpoints: helloWorld: path: /hello-world method: GET handler: helloWorld ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing the increaseScore handler in JavaScript DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript code implements the 'increaseScore' handler function. It retrieves a competitor by ID using the Manifest backend SDK, increments their score, and patches the record with the updated score. It then returns the new score as a JSON response. The handler uses `req.params['id']` to access the `id` route parameter defined in the YAML. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/endpoints.md#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: js CODE: ``` module.exports = async (req, res, manifest) => { // Get the requested competitor with the Manifest backend SDK. const competitor = await manifest .from('competitors') .findOneById(req.params['id']) // Add 1 to the competitor score. const newScore = competitor.score + 1 // Patch the record (changing only specified prop "score"). await manifest.from('competitors').patch(competitor.id, { score: newScore }) // Return updated score. res.json({ newScore }) } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Create New Item via REST API DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows an example HTTP request to create a new item in a collection using the Manifest REST API. The request is a POST request to the /api/collections/:slug endpoint with the item's data in the request body as JSON. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: HTTP CODE: ``` POST /api/collections/pokemons Content-Type: application/json Body: { "name": "Pikachu", "type": "electric", "level": 3, } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Filter List of Items via JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript code shows how to filter a list of cats using the Manifest JS SDK's `where()` and `andWhere()` methods. It demonstrates filtering by breed, active status, and birth date. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` const cats = await manifest .from('cats') .where('breed = siamese') .andWhere('active = true') .andWhere('birthDate > 2020-01-01') .find() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Upload File with JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to upload a file using the Manifest JavaScript SDK. It creates a Blob object, uploads it using the `upload` method, and then uses the returned path to store it in the database. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/upload.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` // Create a Blob, adapt this step to your use case. const file = new Blob(['Hello, this is a test file!'], { type: 'text/plain', }) // Upload a file that will be used as a contract for an invoice. const file = await manifest.from('invoices').upload('contract', file) console.log(file) // Output: {"path":"http://localhost:1111/invoices/contract/Oct2024/8dabo9qm1q3swvu-my-contract.pdf"} // Then you can store the path in the database. const invoice = await manifest.from('invoices').create({ name: 'Invoice ACME', contract: file.path }) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Get List of Items via REST API DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows an example HTTP request to retrieve a list of items from a collection using the Manifest REST API. The request is a GET request to the /api/collection/:slug endpoint. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: HTTP CODE: ``` GET /api/collection/users ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a Password field in Manifest DESCRIPTION: This YAML snippet defines a password field named 'password'. The 'type' is set to 'password', indicating that Manifest will automatically hash the value before storing it. This ensures that passwords are not stored in clear text. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: password, type: password } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining an endpoint for increasing a competitor's score in YAML DESCRIPTION: This YAML code defines an endpoint named 'increaseScore' for a leaderboard application. It specifies the path as '/competitors/:id/increase', allowing for a competitor ID to be passed as a route parameter. The method is set to POST, and the handler is 'increaseScore'. A description is also included for documentation. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/endpoints.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` name: Leaderboard app üèÖ entities: Competitor: properties: - name - { name: score, type: number } endpoints: increaseScore: description: Adds 1 to the competitor score. path: /competitors/:id/increase method: POST handler: increaseScore ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Update Item via REST API DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows an example HTTP request to update an existing item in a collection using the Manifest REST API. The request is a PUT request to the /api/collections/:slug/:id endpoint with the updated item's data in the request body as JSON. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: HTTP CODE: ``` PUT /api/collections/pokemons/25 Content-Type: application/json Body: { "name": "Raichu", "type": "electric", "level": 8 } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Filter By Relation - JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to filter items based on their relation properties using the JavaScript SDK. The `where` method allows specifying conditions on relation properties, requiring the relation to be loaded using `with` first. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_34 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` // Get all cats that belong to owner with id 1. const cats = await manifest .from('cats') .with(['owner']) .where('owner.id = 1') .find() // Get all cats that have an owner with name "Jorge". const cats = await manifest .from('cats') .with(['owner']) .where('owner.name = Jorge') .find() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Update a Single Item - HTTP Request DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to fully update a single item using a PUT request. It includes the new values for all properties of the item in the request body, with the Content-Type set to application/json. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_26 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` PUT /api/singles/homepage Content-Type: application/json Body: { "title": "My new title", "description": "My new description" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: JS SDK Get Current User JavaScript DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript code shows how to get the current logged-in user using the JS SDK. It calls the `manifest.from('contributors').me()` method. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` // Get the current user (logged as Contributor entity). const me = await manifest.from('contributors').me() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Store Relations - JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates storing a new item with relations using the JavaScript SDK. It passes an object containing the new item's properties, including the IDs of the related items. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_37 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` // Store a new player with relations Team and Skill. const newPlayer = await manifest.from('players').create({ name: 'Mike', teamId: 10, skillIds: [1,2,3,4,5] }) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Fetch Data with Manifest SDK in Svelte DESCRIPTION: This Svelte component imports the Manifest SDK, defines an interface for a 'Cat' entity, and uses the `onMount` lifecycle hook to fetch data from the 'cats' endpoint using the Manifest SDK. The fetched data is then displayed in an unordered list. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/svelte.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: typescript CODE: ```
    {#each cats as cat}
  • {cat.name}
    • {/each}
``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Update Relations - JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to update relations using the JavaScript SDK, using both `update` for full replacement and `patch` for partial updates. The `update` method replaces all skill relations, while `patch` only updates the team. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_39 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` // Replaces the whole skill relations by the new skillIds array. await manifest.from('players').update(1, { name: 'Mike', teamId: 10, skillIds: [10, 11] }) // Updates the team without changing the skills or the name. await manifest.from('players').patch(1, {teamId: 5}) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Validation Failure Response (HTTP & JSON) DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates the structure of a validation failure response. The HTTP request shows a POST request attempting to create an employee with an invalid email. The JSON response shows an array of validation errors, indicating the property that failed validation (`email`) and the specific constraint that was violated (`contains`). SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/validation.md#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` // Create a new Employee POST /api/dynamic/employees Content-Type: application/json { "name": "John Doe", "email": "john@manifest.build" } ``` LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` [ { "property": "email", "constraints": { "contains": "The value must contain @company.com" } } ] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: patchDocumentNameIfEmpty Handler in manifest/handlers/patchDocumentNameIfEmpty.js DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript snippet shows a middleware handler that uses the Manifest backend SDK to interact with data. If the `name` property in the request body is empty, it fetches a user from the `users` entity using the user ID from the request body and sets a custom name based on the user's name. The handler uses the Manifest SDK (passed as the third argument). SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/middlewares.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` module.exports = async (req, res, manifest) => { // If the 'name' property of the item is empty. if (!req.body['name']) { // Get the user from the request body. const user = await manifest.from('users').findOneById(req.body['userId']) // Set a custom name based on the user. req.body['name'] = `${user.name}'s untitled document` } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining an Image field in Manifest DESCRIPTION: This YAML snippet defines an image field named 'photo' with options for generating different sizes: small (90x90) and large (width 200). The 'type' is set to 'image', indicating an image upload field. The system stores absolute paths, which can be adapted using the BASE_URL environment variable. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: photo, type: image, options: { sizes: { small: { height: 90, width: 90 }, large: { width: 200 } } } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Fetch Data with Manifest SDK in Vue DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to use the Manifest SDK within a Vue.js component to fetch data from a Manifest backend. It initializes the SDK, specifies the entity to query ('cats'), and processes the response to update the component's state. The code uses TypeScript for type safety but can be adapted to plain JavaScript by removing the typing. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/vue.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: vue CODE: ``` ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: REST API Get Current User Response JSON DESCRIPTION: This JSON response represents the logged-in user data. It returns the user's `id` and `email` after a successful GET request to the `/api/auth/contributors/me` endpoint. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: JSON CODE: ``` { id: 1, email: 'contributor@test.com' } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Initialize Manifest JS SDK DESCRIPTION: Initializes the Manifest JavaScript SDK. The first example initializes the client with the default backend URL (http://localhost:1111), while the second initializes it with a custom base URL. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` import Manifest from '@mnfst/sdk' // Initialize client with default backend URL: http://localhost:1111. const manifest = new Manifest() // Initialize client with custom base URL. const manifest = new Manifest('https://example.com') // Perform CRUD operations... const cats = await manifest.from('cats').find() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Delete an Item (Collection) - HTTP Request DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to delete an item from a collection using a DELETE request. It specifies the collection slug and item ID in the request URL. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_20 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` DELETE api/collections/cats/60 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a Choice field in Manifest DESCRIPTION: This YAML snippet defines two choice fields. The first, named 'sex', provides a choice between 'male' and 'female'. The second, named 'status', provides a choice between 'draft', 'submitted', and 'published', and is marked as 'sequential', indicating a logical order. 'values' is an array of strings representing the available choices. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: sex, type: choice, options: { values: [male, female] } } # Sequential if the values are ordered in a logical sense.. - { name: status, type: choice, options: { values: [draft, submitted, published], sequential: true } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Timestamp Property Definition (YAML) DESCRIPTION: Defines a timestamp property named acquiredAt, using the timestamp type. The format is ISO 8601. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: acquiredAt, type: timestamp } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Inline Validation Syntax (YAML) DESCRIPTION: This snippet showcases the inline syntax for defining validation rules directly within the property object in `backend.yml`. It shows how to apply validation to the `email` and `bio` properties, specifying that the email should not be empty and the bio should have a maximum length of 300 characters. Inline declarations take precedence in case of conflict with block declarations. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/validation.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` entities: Author üßëüèΩ‚Äçü¶±: properties: - name - { name: email, type: email, validation: { isNotEmpty: true } } - { name: bio, type: textarea, validation: { maxLength: 300 } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Get a Single Item - HTTP Response DESCRIPTION: This example shows the JSON response after a successful GET request for the homepage single. It contains the title and description properties. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_24 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "title": "My title", "description": "Welcome to my website!" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Email Property Definition (YAML) DESCRIPTION: Defines an email property named email, using the email type. Validates the input to ensure it is a valid email. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: email, type: email } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Manifest SDK in React (TypeScript) DESCRIPTION: This TypeScript code snippet demonstrates how to use the Manifest SDK to fetch data from a Manifest backend and display it in a React component. It imports the Manifest SDK, initializes it, and uses the `find` method to retrieve a list of `Cat` entities. The fetched data is then stored in a state variable and rendered in a list. This snippet assumes that a Manifest backend is running at `http://localhost:1111` and that a `cats` entity has been created. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/react.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: TypeScript CODE: ``` import Manifest from '@mnfst/sdk'; import { useEffect, useState } from "react"; function App() { interface Cat { id: number; name: string; } const [cats, setCat] = useState([]); useEffect(() => { // Init SDK. const manifest = new Manifest(); // Fetch the list of Cats. manifest.from("cats") .find() .then((res) => { setCat(res.data); }); }, []); // Display a list of Cats. return (
    {cats.map((cat) => (
  • {cat.name}
    • ))}
); } export default App; ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Number Property Definition (YAML) DESCRIPTION: Defines a number property named age, using the number type. Used for storing numerical values. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: age, type: number } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: String Property Definition (YAML) DESCRIPTION: This shows two equivalent ways to define a string property: using the long syntax with 'type: string' and the short syntax without specifying the type. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: firstName, type: string } # Short syntax, same as above. - firstName ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Serve Manifest Backend (Bash) DESCRIPTION: This command starts the Manifest backend server, making the Admin panel and REST API accessible locally. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/introduction.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` npm run manifest ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: File Property Definition (YAML) DESCRIPTION: Defines a file property named document, using the file type. Allows file uploads. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: document, type: file } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Create Svelte App DESCRIPTION: This command creates a new Svelte app using SvelteKit, navigates into the app directory, installs dependencies, and starts the development server. It assumes npm is installed and configured. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/svelte.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` npm create svelte@latest my-client cd my-client npm install npm run dev -- --open ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Upload Image with JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to upload an image using the Manifest JavaScript SDK. It includes converting a base64 string to a Blob, uploading the image using the `uploadImage` method, and storing the returned image paths (thumbnail and medium) in the database. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/upload.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` // Create a Blob from an image, adapt this step to your use case. const base64Image = 'iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mP8/wcAAwAB/eb7jLwAAAAASUVORK5CYII=' const imageBlob: Blob = base64ToBlob(base64Image, 'image/png') // Upload the image. const image = await manifest.from('cats').uploadImage('avatar', imageBlob) console.log(image) // Output: { // "medium": "http://localhost:1111/cats/avatar/Oct2024/8dabo9qm1q4n1nk-medium.jpg", // "thumbnail": "http://localhost:1111/cats/avatar/Oct2024/8dabo9qm1q4n1nk-thumbnail.jpg" // } // Then you can store the path in the database. const cat = await manifest.from('cats').create({ name: 'Felix', image: image }) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining a Location field in Manifest DESCRIPTION: This YAML snippet defines a location field named 'location'. The 'type' is set to 'location', indicating that it will store an object with 'lat' and 'lng' coordinates. This allows storing geographic coordinates. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_19 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: location, type: location } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: S3 Configuration Variables in .env DESCRIPTION: Defines the required environment variables for configuring S3 storage. These variables specify the S3 bucket name, endpoint, region, access key ID, and secret access key. They need to be present in the `.env` file. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/s3-storage.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: env CODE: ``` S3_BUCKET=my-bucket-name S3_ENDPOINT=https://your-s3-provider.com S3_REGION=XXX S3_ACCESS_KEY_ID=XXX S3_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=XXX ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Webhook HTTP Request Body (JSON) DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows the structure of the JSON body that Manifest sends with webhook HTTP requests. It includes the `event`, `createdAt`, `entity`, and `record` fields. The `record` field contains the data associated with the entity, either before or after the event. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/webhooks.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "event": "beforeUpdate", "createdAt": "2025-01-22T13:38:48.399Z", "entity": "posts", "record": { "title": "my title", "content": "my content" } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Validate Optional Properties (YAML) DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to validate optional properties using the `isOptional` validator in `backend.yml`. It shows an example for the `email` property, where the email is only validated if it's provided (not null or undefined), ensuring that it contains "@company.com". This allows for conditional validation based on the presence of the property. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/validation.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` entities: Employee: properties: - name - { name: email, type: email, validation: { contains: '@company.com', isOptional: true } } # If provided, the email should contain "@company.com" ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Adding Production Start Script DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to add a production start script to the `package.json` file. The script executes the main JavaScript file of the Manifest application, enabling production deployment using `npm run start`. This approach ensures that the application runs correctly in a production setting. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/deploy.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` "scripts": { "start": "node node_modules/manifest/dist/manifest/src/main.js" [...] } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: More Entity Policies YAML DESCRIPTION: This YAML snippet provides additional examples of entity policy configurations, showcasing different access types and allowed entities for read, create, update, delete, and signup operations. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: YAML CODE: ``` entities: Project üóÇÔ∏è: properties: - name policies: read: - { access: restricted, allow: [Contributor, Manager] } # Only some entities (and admins). create: - { access: restricted, allow: Manager } # Only managers (and admins). update: - access: üë®üèª‚Äçüíª # Only admin. delete: - access: üö´ # Forbidden (no one). Contributor üë®‚Äçüíº: authenticable: true properties: - name policies: signup: - access: üö´ # Forbidden (no one). create: - { access: üîí, allow: Manager } # Managers can create contributors. update: - { access: üîí, allow: Manager } delete: - { access: üîí, allow: Manager } # Managers can create contributors. ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Create and Initialize Vue App DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to create a new Vue.js application using the Vue CLI, navigate into the project directory, install dependencies, and start the development server. It uses npm to manage the Vue project. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/vue.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` npm create vue@latest cd my-client // If you called your app "my-client" when asked in the previous step npm install npm run dev ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Using Manifest SDK in Angular Component DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to import the Manifest SDK, initialize it, and use it to fetch data (cats in this case) inside an Angular component. It uses the `find()` method to retrieve a list of entities from the Manifest backend. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/angular.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` import { Component } from '@angular/core' import Manifest from '@mnfst/sdk' @Component({ selector: 'app-root', templateUrl: './app.component.html', styleUrls: ['./app.component.css'] }) export class AppComponent { cats: { id: number, name: string }[] = [] async ngOnInit() { // Init SDK. const manifest = new Manifest() // Fetch the list of Cats. const result = await manifest.from('cats').find() this.cats = result.data } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Fetching and Displaying Data with Manifest SDK in Astro DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to use the Manifest SDK within an Astro component to fetch data and render it in the HTML. It initializes the SDK, fetches a list of 'cats' entities using the `from('cats').find()` method, and then maps over the resulting data to display the cat names in a list. Make sure the Manifest backend is running and configured with a 'cats' entity. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/astro.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` --- import Manifest from '@mnfst/sdk' // Init SDK. const manifest = new Manifest() // Fetch the cat list. const result = await manifest.from('cats').find() const cats = result.data --- Astro
    { cats.map((cat) => (
  • {cat.name}
    • )) }
``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example HTTP Response for List of Items DESCRIPTION: This JSON represents the HTTP response from the REST API when fetching a list of items. It contains the data array with the items, pagination information such as the current page, last page, total number of items, and items per page. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: JSON CODE: ``` { "data": [ { "id": 1, "name": "Lara" }, { "id": 2, "name": "Karl" } ], "currentPage": 1, "lastPage": 1, "from": 1, "to": 10, "total": 3, "perPage": 10 } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Update Relations - HTTP Request DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to update relations using both PUT (full replacement) and PATCH (partial replacement) requests in the REST API. PUT replaces all skill relations, while PATCH only updates the team relation. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_38 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` // Replaces the whole skill relations by the new skillIds array. PUT http://localhost:1111/api/dynamic/players/1 Content-Type: application/json { name: 'Mike', teamId: 10, skillIds: [10, 11] } // Updates the team without changing the skills or the name. PATCH http://localhost:1111/api/dynamic/players/1 Content-Type: application/json { teamId: 5, } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Patch an Item (Collection) - JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to partially update a Pokemon item using the JavaScript SDK's `patch` method. It takes the item's ID and an object containing the properties to update. It returns a promise that resolves to the updated item. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_19 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` // Patches the Pokemon item with ID 25. const newPokemon = await manifest.from('pokemons').patch(25, { level: 5 }) console.log(newPokemon); // Output: { // id: 25, // name: "Pikachu", // type: "electric", // level: 5 // } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: REST API Login Response JSON DESCRIPTION: This JSON response shows the format of a successful login request. The response contains a JWT token that should be included in the `Authorization` header of subsequent requests using the `Bearer` scheme. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: JSON CODE: ``` { "token": "12345" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: JS SDK Login JavaScript DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript code snippet shows how to log in as an admin or user using the JS SDK. It uses the `manifest.login()` method, passing in the entity type, email, and password. Subsequent requests will automatically include the authorization token in the header. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` // Login as Admin. await manifest.login('admins', 'admin@manifest.build', 'password') // Login as User entity. await manifest.login('users', 'user@example.com', 'password') // Then all following requests will have the authorization token in their header until logout. const example = await manifest.from('restricted-resource').find() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Get List of Items via JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript code demonstrates how to retrieve a list of users using the Manifest JS SDK. It uses the `from()` method to specify the entity and the `find()` method to retrieve all users. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_4 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` // Get all users. const users = await manifest.from('users').find() console.log(users); // Output: { // "data": [ // { // "id": 1, // "name": "Lara" // }, // { // "id": 2, // "name": "Karl" // } // ], // "currentPage": 1, // "lastPage": 1, // "from": 1, // "to": 10, // "total": 3, // "perPage": 10 // } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Defining Middlewares in manifest/backend.yml DESCRIPTION: This YAML snippet shows how to define middlewares for an entity in the `manifest/backend.yml` file. It specifies the `beforeCreate` and `afterCreate` events and associates handler functions with them. These handlers will be executed before and after a new record is created in the database. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/middlewares.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` entities: Project üóÇÔ∏è: properties: - name - { name: date, type: date } middlewares: beforeCreate: - handler: setDate afterCreate: - handler: sendEmail ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Implementing a handler function in JavaScript DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript code defines the handler function 'helloWorld' that is executed when the '/hello-world' endpoint is accessed. It takes the request (req) and response (res) objects as arguments and sends a JSON response containing a 'message' property. This function should be placed in the `/manifest/handlers/helloWorld.js` file. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/endpoints.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: js CODE: ``` module.exports = async (req, res) => { res.json({ message: 'Hello world from my new endpoint!' }) } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: REST API Signup Response JSON DESCRIPTION: This JSON response represents the successful signup. The response returns a JWT token that must be added to the `Authorization` header of subsequent API calls using the `Bearer` scheme. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: JSON CODE: ``` { "token": "12345" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Store Relations - HTTP Request DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to store a new item with relations using the REST API. The request body includes the IDs of the related items as properties ending with 'Id' for many-to-one and 'Ids' for many-to-many relations. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_36 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` // Store a new player with relations Team and Skill. POST http://localhost:1111/api/dynamic/players Content-Type: application/json { "name": "Mike", "teamId": 10, "skillIds": [1,2,3,4,5] } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Upload File with REST API DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to upload a file using the Manifest REST API. It outlines the required POST request to the `/api/upload/file` endpoint with a `multipart/form-data` content type and provides the expected response. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/upload.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` // Upload file. POST /api/upload/file Content-Type: multipart/form-data { file: (binary) entity: invoices property: contract } // Response. { "path":"http://localhost:1111/invoices/contract/Oct2024/8dabo9qm1q3swvu-my-contract.pdf" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: setDate Handler in manifest/handlers/setDate.js DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript snippet demonstrates a simple middleware handler function. It logs a message to the console and sets the `date` property in the request body to the current date. This handler is intended to be triggered `beforeCreate` event. It receives `req` and `res` arguments. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/middlewares.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` module.exports = async (req, res) => { console.log('Hello from the handler!') req.body['date'] = new Date() } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Order List of Items via JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript code demonstrates how to order a list of cats using the Manifest JS SDK. It uses the `orderBy()` method to specify the property to order by and the `desc` option to indicate descending order. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` // Order cats. const cats = await manifest.from('cats').orderBy('age', { desc: true }).find() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Define a Single Entity (YAML) DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines a single entity, ContactPage, with title, content, and image properties. It includes the 'single: true' setting, a slug, and validation rules for the title property. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` ContactPage: single: true slug: contact properties: - { name: title, type: string } - { name: content, type: text } - { name: image, type: image } validation: title: { required: true } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Update Item via JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript code demonstrates how to update an existing Pokemon item with ID 25 using the Manifest JS SDK. It uses the `update()` method, passing the ID and an object containing the properties to be updated. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_16 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` // Updates the Pokemon item with ID 25. const newPokemon = await manifest.from('pokemons').update(25, { name: "Raichu", type: "electric", level: 8, }) console.log(newPokemon); // Output: { // id: 25, // name: "Raichu", // type: "electric", // level: 8 // } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Entity Policy Configuration YAML DESCRIPTION: This YAML snippet demonstrates how to configure API policies for an entity. It defines access rules for create, update, and delete operations, specifying which entities are allowed to perform each operation. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: YAML CODE: ``` entities: Invoice üßæ: properties: - number - { name: issueDate, type: date } policies: create: - { access: restricted, allow: User } update: - access: admin delete: - access: forbidden ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Create New Item via JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript code demonstrates how to create a new item in the 'pokemons' entity using the Manifest JS SDK. It uses the `create()` method, passing an object with the properties of the new item. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_13 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` // Create a new item in the "pokemons" entity. const newPokemon = await manifest.from('pokemons').create({ name: "Pikachu", type: "electric", level: 3, }) console.log(newPokemon); // Output: { // id: 25, // name: "Pikachu", // type: "electric", // level: 3 // } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Patch a Single Item - JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to partially update the homepage single using the JavaScript SDK's `patch` method. It only provides the 'title' property to update, leaving other properties untouched. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_31 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` // Update single entity partially. const homepage = await manifest.single('homepage').patch({ title: 'My new title' }) console.log(homepage) // Output: { // title: "My new title", // description: "Welcome to my website!" // } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: JS SDK Signup JavaScript DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript snippet demonstrates how to sign up a new user using the JS SDK. It calls `manifest.signup()` to create an account. Following requests made with the SDK will automatically include the received authentication token. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` // Sign up as a new user. await manifest.signup('users', 'user@example.com', 'password') // Then all following requests will have the authorization token in its header until logout. const example = await manifest.from('restricted-resource').find() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Update a Single Item - JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to update a single item using the JavaScript SDK's `single` and `update` methods. It passes an object containing the new values for the item's properties. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_28 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` // Update single entity. const newHomepage = await manifest.single('homepage').update({ title: 'My new title', description: 'My new description' }) console.log(newHomepage); // Output: { // title: "My new title", // description: "My new description" // } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Delete an Item (Collection) - JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to delete a cat item using the JavaScript SDK's `delete` method. It takes the item's ID as an argument and returns a promise that resolves to the deleted item. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_22 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` // Delete the cat with ID 60. const deletedCat = await manifest.from('cats').delete(60) console.log(deletedCat); // Output: { // name: "Fido", // description: "A cute black cat" // } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Dockerfile Configuration DESCRIPTION: This Dockerfile configures a container for running the Manifest application. It uses a Node.js base image, copies package files, installs dependencies, copies application code, sets the environment to production, exposes a port, and defines a command to start the application. This setup streamlines the deployment process using Docker. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/deploy.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: dockerfile CODE: ``` # Use the official Node.js image as a base FROM node:18-slim # Copy package.json and package-lock.json (if available) COPY package*.json ./ # Install dependencies RUN npm install && npm cache clean --force && rm -rf /root/.npm && rm -rf /tmp/* # Copy the rest of your application code COPY . . # Set the NODE_ENV environment variable ENV NODE_ENV=production # Expose the port the app runs on (adjust as needed) EXPOSE 1111 # Start the application CMD ["npm", "run", "start"] ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Enable Authenticable Entity YAML DESCRIPTION: This YAML snippet configures an entity to be authenticable, allowing users to log in with it. It adds the `authenticable: true` property to the entity definition, automatically providing `email` and `password` fields for authentication. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: YAML CODE: ``` entities: Patient ü§í: authenticable: true # Makes entity authenticable. properties: - name ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Load Relations - HTTP Request DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to load relations with entities using the REST API. The `relations` query parameter specifies which relations should be included in the query, including nested relations. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_33 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` // Fetch entities with 2 relations. GET http://localhost:1111/api/dynamic/city?relations=region,mayor // Fetch nested relations. GET http://localhost:111/api/dynamic/city?relations=region,region.country,region.country.planet ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Get a Single Item - JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to retrieve a single item using the JavaScript SDK's `single` and `get` methods. It retrieves the homepage entity and logs its contents to the console. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_25 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` // Get the homepage entity. const homepage = await manifest.single('homepage').get() console.log(homepage); // Output: { // title: "My title", // description: "Welcome to my website!" // } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Load Relations - JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to load relations with entities using the JavaScript SDK. The `with` method specifies which relations should be included in the query, including nested relations. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_32 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` // Fetch entities with 2 relations. const cities = await manifest .from('cities') .with(['region', 'mayor']) .find() // Fetch nested relations. const cities = await manifest .from('cities') .with(['region', 'region.country', 'region.country.planet']) .find() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: REST API Login Request HTTP DESCRIPTION: This HTTP request example shows how to log in as an admin or an authenticable entity using the REST API. It sends a POST request to the `/api/auth/admins/login` endpoint with the user's email and password in the request body. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: HTTP CODE: ``` POST /api/auth/admins/login Content-Type: application/json { "email": "admin@manifest.build", "password": "password" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Paginate List of Items via JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript code shows how to paginate a list of cats using the Manifest JS SDK. It uses the `find()` method with the `page` and `perPage` parameters to specify the desired page and number of items per page. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` const cats = await manifest.from('cats').find({ page: 1, perPage: 10 }) ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Patch an Item (Collection) - HTTP Request DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to partially update an item within a collection using a PATCH request. It modifies only the 'level' property of the Pokemon with ID 25. The content type is set to application/json. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_17 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` PATCH /api/collections/pokemons/25 Content-Type: application/json Body: { "level": 5, } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Filter By Relation - HTTP Request DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to filter items by relation properties using the REST API. It uses query parameters to specify the relation and the property to filter by. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_35 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` // Get all cats that belong to owner with id 1. GET http://localhost:1111/api/dynamic/cats?relations=owner&owner.id_eq=1 // Get all cats that have an owner with name "Jorge". GET http://localhost:1111/api/dynamic/cats?relations=owner&owner.name_eq=Jorge ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a React App DESCRIPTION: This snippet uses `create-react-app` to scaffold a new React project. It also navigates to the newly created directory and starts the development server. Requires Node.js and npm to be installed. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/react.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` npx create-react-app my-client cd my-client npm start ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Manifest SDK DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to install the Manifest SDK using npm. This SDK provides the necessary tools to interact with the Manifest backend from your Vue.js application. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/vue.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` npm i @mnfst/sdk ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example HTTP Response for Create New Item DESCRIPTION: This JSON represents the HTTP response after successfully creating a new item via the REST API. It contains the details of the newly created item, including its ID. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_12 LANGUAGE: JSON CODE: ``` { "id": 25, "name": "Pikachu", "type": "electric", "level": 3, } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: REST API Signup Request HTTP DESCRIPTION: This HTTP request example shows how to sign up a new user using the REST API. It sends a POST request to the `/api/auth/users/signup` endpoint with the new user's email and password. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_5 LANGUAGE: HTTP CODE: ``` POST /api/auth/users/signup Content-Type: application/json { "email": "user@example.com", "password": "password" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Patch an Item (Collection) - HTTP Response DESCRIPTION: This example shows the JSON response after a successful PATCH request to update a Pokemon item. The response includes the updated 'level' property and the other unchanged properties. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_18 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "id": 25, "name": "Pikachu", "type": "electric", "level": 5 } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: MySQL/MariaDB .env Configuration DESCRIPTION: This snippet configures a Manifest application to use MySQL or MariaDB. It sets DB_CONNECTION to mysql and specifies the database username, password, host, port, database name, and SSL setting. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/config.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: env CODE: ``` DB_CONNECTION=mysql DB_USERNAME=xxxxx DB_PASSWORD=xxxxx DB_HOST=my-host.com DB_PORT=25060 DB_DATABASE=my_app DB_SSL=true # Required for remote managed DBs, remove if local ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Displaying data in Angular template DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to display the fetched data (cats array) in an Angular template using `*ngFor` directive. The `cat.name` property is displayed for each cat in the array. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/angular.md#_snippet_3 LANGUAGE: HTML CODE: ```
  • {{ cat.name }}
``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Get Single Item via JS SDK DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript code demonstrates how to retrieve a single cat item by its ID using the Manifest JS SDK. It uses the `findOneById()` method with the ID as the parameter. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` // Get cat with ID 34 const cat = await manifest.from('cats').findOneById(34) console.log(cat); // Output: { // name: "Mina", // description": "A really cute cat" // } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Manifest SDK DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to install the Manifest SDK using npm. It should be executed from the root directory of your Angular project. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/angular.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` npm i @mnfst/sdk ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Patch a Single Item - HTTP Request DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates partially updating a single item with a PATCH request. It modifies only the 'title' property of the homepage single. The content type is set to application/json. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_29 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` PATCH /api/singles/homepage Content-Type: application/json Body: { "title": "My new title", } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: PostgreSQL .env Configuration DESCRIPTION: This snippet configures a Manifest application to use PostgreSQL. It sets DB_CONNECTION to postgres and specifies the database host, username, password, database name, and SSL setting. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/config.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: env CODE: ``` DB_CONNECTION=postgres DB_HOST=my-host.com DB_USERNAME=owner DB_PASSWORD=xxxxx DB_DATABASE=my_app DB_SSL=true # Required for remote managed DBs, remove if local ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Manifest SDK (npm) DESCRIPTION: This command installs the Manifest SDK package (`@mnfst/sdk`) as a dependency for your Astro project. It allows your Astro application to interact with a Manifest backend, enabling data fetching and manipulation. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/astro.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` npm i @mnfst/sdk ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example HTTP Response for Update Item DESCRIPTION: This JSON represents the HTTP response after successfully updating an item via the REST API. It contains the details of the updated item. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_15 LANGUAGE: JSON CODE: ``` { "id": 25, "name": "Raichu", "type": "electric", "level": 8 } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: PNPM Configuration (JSON) DESCRIPTION: This JSON snippet configures PNPM to include specific dependencies when installing. This addresses an incompatibility issue where PNPM blocks postinstall scripts required by Manifest. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/introduction.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "pnpm": { "onlyBuiltDependencies": [ "@nestjs/core", "sharp", "sqlite3" ] } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Manifest SDK DESCRIPTION: This command installs the Manifest SDK as a dependency to your Svelte project. It requires npm to be installed and configured in the project. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/svelte.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` npm i @mnfst/sdk ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: JS SDK Logout JavaScript DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript snippet demonstrates how to log out using the JS SDK. It calls the `manifest.logout()` method to remove the token from future requests. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: JavaScript CODE: ``` // All future calls will lose the "Authorization" header. await manifest.logout() ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Get Single Item via REST API DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows an example HTTP request to retrieve a single item from a collection using the Manifest REST API. The request is a GET request to the /api/collections/:slug/:id endpoint. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: HTTP CODE: ``` GET /api/collections/cats/34 ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Delete an Item (Collection) - HTTP Response DESCRIPTION: This example shows the JSON response after a successful DELETE request for a cat item. The response includes the properties of the deleted item. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_21 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "name": "Fido", "description": "A cute black cat" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Example HTTP Response for Single Item DESCRIPTION: This JSON represents the HTTP response when fetching a single item from the REST API. It contains the details of the requested item. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: JSON CODE: ``` { "name": "Mina", "description": "A really cute cat" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Patch a Single Item - HTTP Response DESCRIPTION: This example shows the JSON response after a successful PATCH request. The title is updated while the description remains unchanged. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_30 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "title": "My new title", "description": "Welcome to my website!" } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Installing Manifest SDK DESCRIPTION: This command installs the Manifest SDK from npm. It should be run from the root directory of your React app. Requires npm to be installed. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/react.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` npm i @mnfst/sdk ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Seed Dummy Data (JavaScript) DESCRIPTION: This command generates dummy data for all entities defined in the backend.yml file. It's useful for development and testing purposes. However, it should not be used in production environments, as it replaces existing data. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_1 LANGUAGE: javascript CODE: ``` npm run manifest:seed ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: SQLite .env Configuration DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to configure a Manifest application to use SQLite by setting the DB_CONNECTION to sqlite and specifying the path to the database file using DB_PATH. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/config.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: env CODE: ``` DB_CONNECTION=sqlite DB_PATH=/manifest/backend.db ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Get a Single Item - HTTP Request DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to retrieve a single item using a GET request. It specifies the single's slug in the request URL. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_23 LANGUAGE: http CODE: ``` GET /api/singles/homepage ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Manifest JS SDK DESCRIPTION: Installs the Manifest JavaScript SDK using npm. This SDK provides a human-friendly interface for interacting with the Manifest backend from a JavaScript client. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` npm i @mnfst/sdk ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Boolean Property Definition (YAML) DESCRIPTION: Defines a boolean property named isActive, using the boolean type. Used for true or false values. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_14 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: isActive, type: boolean } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Configure Entity Parameters (YAML) DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to configure parameters such as seedCount and mainProp for an entity. It also shows how to define multiple properties including firstName, lastName, and email. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_2 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` entities: Member üë§: seedCount: 200 mainProp: lastName properties: - firstName - lastName - email ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Install Manifest CLI (Bash) DESCRIPTION: This command installs the Manifest CLI globally, allowing you to scaffold a new Manifest project or add Manifest to an existing project. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/introduction.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: bash CODE: ``` npx add-manifest@latest ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Textarea Property Definition (YAML) DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines a textarea property named description, using the text type. This is used for medium sized text inputs. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_6 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: description, type: text } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Rich Text Property Definition (YAML) DESCRIPTION: This defines a rich text property named description, using the richText type. This allows for HTML content to be stored and edited. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_7 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: description, type: richText } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Link Property Definition (YAML) DESCRIPTION: Defines a link property named website, using the link type. This is used for external URLs. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_9 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: website, type: link } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Money Property Definition (YAML) DESCRIPTION: Defines a money property named price, using the money type, and specifies the currency as EUR. It only allows 2 digits after the comma. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_10 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: price, type: money, options: { currency: 'EUR' } } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Date Property Definition (YAML) DESCRIPTION: Defines a date property named startDate, using the date type. Basic date field. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/entities.md#_snippet_11 LANGUAGE: yaml CODE: ``` - { name: startDate, type: date } ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating an Astro App (npm) DESCRIPTION: This command initializes a new Astro project. It uses the `create-astro@latest` package to scaffold the project and sets up the development environment. `my-astro-app` is the suggested project name, and the subsequent command navigates into the created directory. Finally, `npm run dev` starts the local development server. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/astro.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: shell CODE: ``` npm create astro@latest cd my-astro-app npm run dev ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Creating a new Angular app DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to create a new Angular application using the Angular CLI. It also navigates into the created directory and starts the development server. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/angular.md#_snippet_0 LANGUAGE: Shell CODE: ``` ng new my-client cd my-client ng serve ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: REST API Get Current User HTTP DESCRIPTION: This HTTP request example retrieves the current logged-in user using the REST API. It sends a GET request to the `/api/auth/contributors/me` endpoint with the `Authorization` header containing the JWT token. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/auth.md#_snippet_8 LANGUAGE: HTTP CODE: ``` GET /api/auth/contributors/me Content-Type: application/json Authorization: Bearer your-token-here ``` ---------------------------------------- TITLE: Update a Single Item - HTTP Response DESCRIPTION: This example shows the JSON response after a successful PUT request to update the homepage single. It reflects the updated title and description. SOURCE: https://github.com/mnfst/docs/blob/master/crud.md#_snippet_27 LANGUAGE: json CODE: ``` { "title": "My new title", "description": "My new description" } ```
